title: Which presidential candidate will win Pennsylvania?
preds: Getting off my high horse for a sec, but Biden should still win.
I need to look at the info, but if the remaining uncounted votes heavily favor as they have been in other places then Biden should win this one.
Biden is ahead by over a million votes going into tomorrow. That is a huge deficit to overcome.
Outside of Philadelphia and some surrounding suburbs, Trump has overwhelming support throughout the state.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Considering voting history in past couple of decades and very close in 2016.

Biden continues to lead by over 5 points in almost every poll out of the state, Pennsylvania is historically blue, and Trump has done little to win it over. Instead of appealing to voters, the GOP is trying to make it harder for voters to cast their ballots in the election, a clear sign he does not think he is going to win the state. Over half of mail-in ballots have already been cast, voters are turning out at exceptionally high rates, and Trump has no clear path to victory in the coming days.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

Franklin and Marshall Pennsylvania, Nov 1, 2016. 
            Clinton +11 
https://www.fandm.edu/news/latest-news/2016/11/01/clinton-s-lead-widens-in-pennsylvania-f-m-poll-shows Franklin And Marshall Pennsylvania, Oct 29th, 2020
Biden +6
https://www.fandm.edu/news/latest-news/2020/10/29/f-m-poll-six-days-before-election-biden-leads-trump-by-six-points-in-pennsylvania Pennsylvania actual 2016 
Donald J. Trump 2,970,733 48.2%  Hillary Clinton 2,926,441 47.5%

I still think Biden will win but increasingly seeing news items like this: https://www.forbes.com/sites/jackbrewster/2020/10/28/todays-2020-election-polls-bidens-up-big-in-wisconsin-and-michigan-but-not-pennsylvania/.
There is almost no chance Biden loses this state at this point as early voting has tipped heavily in Dems favor.

Pennsylvania 7th Congressional District poll: https://www.wfmz.com/news/area/lehighvalley/desales-university-wfmz-poll-shows-biden-widening-lead-in-7th-district/article_978ef8de-17d5-11eb-b0d7-e3e6882ef355.html
Biden +19. In a geographic area that Hillary won by only 1. This is a heavily gerrymandered district that was supposed to be safe R.  A lot of this is Philly suburbs, demographically 70% White in this district. Lots of luck suppressing that vote. At this point, the idea that Trump has any chance in PA feels like gaslighting. Therefore putting all my chips on Biden here.

Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Biden looks good to win in PA
Biden continues to lead in Pennsylvania. [1] [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/pennsylvania/

In 2016, trump beat last RCP average in Pennsylvania by 3.9 points. Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average, 270towin current average , Economist prediction and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 47.6% for trump to Biden's 49.3%. Seven day momentum was in trump's favor, improving his position by 1.4%.

In 2016, trump beat last RCP average in Pennsylvania by 3.9 points. Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average, 270towin current average , Economist prediction and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 47.2% for trump to Biden's 50%. Seven day momentum was in Biden's favor, , improving his position by 0.85%.
Biden's lead continues to grow, posting a 0.4 point increase in just a few days. Trump doesn't have the policy, capital, or clout to pull an upset here.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

Since the debate, Biden's lead in Pennsylvania has ballooned to a near 7 point average margin. Trump not only attacked the state during the debate (claiming "bad things happen' in its largest city) but has never held a lead there and continues to drop in support. With less than 4 weeks remaining until the election, Biden should have this one in the bag. He is outraising and outspending Trump, Pennsylvania is historically blue, and newer polls only show his lead growing (yesterday's Quinnipiac poll shows him up 13 points and Monmouth polls show him up double digits). It's clear Trump's debate performance sealed his fate in this state (which he was unlikely to win again anyway) and so long as Biden doesn't make any huge mistakes between now and the election, its all but over.

This forecast was programmatically produced by taking the (deluxe) 538 prediction and making a calibration adjustment unless this brought probability to <10%. Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)

Increasing my expectation of Trump winning based on the possibility of an end run by the legislature.

In 2016, trump beat last RCP average in Pennsylvania by 3.9 points. Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 47.9% for trump to Biden's 48.3%.

Biden continues to poll around 5 points ahead [1,2]. No poll this year puts Trump ahead of any democrat, let alone Biden [2]. The info from @Daveinsea [3] is a good reminder that polls aren't the full thing, but I have a vague memory of similar optimistic comments from the Clinton campaign in 2016 about states where things were running close, so am taking that read with a grain of salt. [1] https://electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Pres/Graphs/pennsylvania.html
[2] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/pennsylvania/
[3] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1129189
Ok going with crowd on this.
Cook Political rates this as a toss-up. https://dknation.draftkings.com/2020/7/28/21344736/pennsylvania-presidential-polls-2020-general-election-donald-trump-vs-joe-biden-538-new-york-times

EBO: 64% (-2)
FTE: 74%
FTE polls: Biden 5% (-1)
Crowd: 75% (-5)
Most votes are locked in. Biden consistently ahead of Trump. Trump has pulled some advertising from Pennsylvania.
Updated based on recent polls with Biden up between 2-6% of LV
Upgrading slightly based on FiveThirtyEight's current model. [1] [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/pennsylvania/
Biden has slipped here but still should come out ahead
Biden's polling advantage continues in recent weeks and while margins vary most indicate he has a fair lead.

2016 Voted for DT: 48.2%
GOP state win: 36.4%
DT 538: 31%
Crowd: 24%
Lowering my confidence based on this forecast: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/election-update-biden-gets-good-polls-in-arizona-and-wisconsin-and-a-bad-one-in-pennsylvania/
Biden has maintained a lead in all polls but one (done end of May) since March.  Current RCP avg has him up +4.2.
Biden's lead in polling is holding steady throughout August.
Biden has been consistently polling higher than Trump.

Pennsylvania is now the most likely tipping point state.  Average of
https://projects.economist.com/us-2020-forecast/president/pennsylvania
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/pennsylvania/

Upshot? Trump has a chance. Much of the rural country is not ready for diversity and inclusion. (Sadly they see a them when it could be an us) Race will tighten. Big Cities probably outvote rural areas so Biden squeaks out a win but not a certainty.
Updating to reflect recent polling showing a narrower lead for Biden.

Donald Trump was the first Republican to win Pennsylvania since Bush '88, and he did so only by a narrow margin. With Biden up by almost 7 percentage points at the moment and trending upward, it is unlikely Trump will be able to prevent the flip this time around.

Outside refers to previous Pennsylvania Presidential election outcomes and Inside refers to the specific circumstances of the 2020 Pennsylvania Presidential Election. Post WWII, Pennsylvania has voted 10 times (D) Democratic and 8 times (R) Republican in the US Presidential Elections from 1948 - 2016 ->
D(outside) = 56% = 10/18
R(outside) = 44% =   8/18 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_wall_(politics)#In_presidential_elections   Given the Republican & Democratic Dominance in Pennsylvania I will assume that ->
Other Party = 0% Looking Inside, Pennsylvania is universally viewed as leaning Democratic for 2020 -> 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election_in_Pennsylvania#Predictions   Averaging these predictions I give ->
D(inside) = 62.5%
R(inside) = 37.5% = 100% - 62.5% In choosing the weighting between Outside and Inside, I decided that ->
W(outside) << W(inside) 
           0.25 << 0.75 Why I chose this was in 2016, Democrats had a weak candidate with a poor economic message combined with Republicans winning the popular vote extremely narrowly. In 2020, Trump is presiding over an economy in recession and a failed ability in controlling the pandemic and Joe Biden I believe understands and is more in touch with Pennsylvania voters' concerns than Clinton. All this makes me conclude that Pennsylvania in 2020 will be less a swing state as shown with Outside but more a likely Democratic Presidential state as expressed with Inside. From this I calculated that ->
D = 61% = 56% * 0.25 + 62.5% * 0.75 
R = 39% = 44% * 0.25 + 37.5% * 0.75 Given these percentages are relatively mild, I will push these values more to their respective extremes ->
D = 76% = 61% * 1.25
R = 24% = 100% - 76% Democratic Win in Pennsylvania for 2020 Presidential Election = 76%
Republican Win in Pennsylvania for 2020 Presidential Election = 24%
Other Win in Pennsylvania for 2020 Presidential Election = 0%
Consistent polls showing Biden ahead for months coupled with RCP average showing Biden +6.6
Latest Monmouth poll has Biden up, 53 to 40 in PA.
White working class demographics will be very important.  Much like 2016.  African Americans turnout even if close to 100 percent will matter little in a 80% white state

SC/NYT, the top-rated most recent poll tracked by FiveThirtyEight, gives Biden a pretty massive double-digit lead over incumbent Donald Trump.[1][2] To me this puts Biden on firm footing as the final month of the race go ahead. Hence a borderline "Probable" rating in his favour. Updates to follow. [1]https://scri.siena.edu/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/PA0620-Crosstabs062520H.pdf
[2]https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/pennsylvania/
Cook Political Report just moved PA and WI from “toss up” to “lean Democrat.”
Biden will win in every Rust Belt state. Workers love him, and they now know for certain Trump could not care less about them or their families.
My new 2020 election forecast just launched at plusminusforecasts.com!
Biden dominating polls and opening up several double-digit leads.

Biden polling consistently 5-12 points ahead [1,2]. That and his tight history with the state seems to make it more likely. [1] https://electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Pres/Graphs/pennsylvania.html
[2] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/pennsylvania/
Biden is from PA and holds a six point lead there right now. Very little chance he loses this state.
Unpredictability of Covid-19 will play against the President's style of governing by instinct and his own unpredictability.
Based on current state polls, as well as Democrats’ 2018 mid-term performance here, I think this one is “Likely Biden”.

Additional high quality polling today showing Biden ahead in PA. Matches national trends and seeing similar data out of other Midwestern states.  https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/pennsylvania/
Biden +10 in latest NYT/Siena College survey.

As the polling stands and based on firsthand perspectives of family in PA. Note: VP pick will be essential here, needing to be more moderate to win mid-state. https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/us/general_election_trump_vs_biden-6247.html
Polling averages only growing wider in states similar to Pennsylvania.

This looks to be a close race, but I believe several things tip the vote to Biden. First, the states governor is a democrat, this helps. Second, Pennsylvania is another big prize the Democratic machine will spend time and money on. Third, I believe this will be a continued indictment of Donald Trump, as battleground states that went to him in 2016, will turn their back on him now.
Covid-19, immigration, and "law and order" will trigger better turnout among minorities and young voters, all to benefit of dems. And Biden will be portrayed as a native son.
Latest polls show Trump ahead there.

Trump has lost a lot of his support among the suburban voters. If African Americans turn out, he will not win. If rural voters turn out and suburban voters sit on their hands, Trump wins. I don't see that happening. I think he has alienated many suburban voters (especially women) and particularly independents.
Biden is strong in PA and Trump's base will not be enough.

All high quality polling from April showed Biden ahead. Polling since has been a mixture of quality, but mostly has shown Biden ahead. Given national environment, can’t imagine this has changed in a worse direction for Biden. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/pennsylvania/ PA will still tend towards a swing state though. Hard to lean too hard in the direction of Biden without more data.

While Biden is polling well, I suspect that in the end, with so much chaos, that Republicans will vote Republican because they will be afraid of more change. Outlying factors include who Biden chooses for VP and whether Trump can keep from going too far off the rails. But we have seen it before ... some people will vote Trump no matter what.
Biden will win Pennsylvania, if he doesn't then it'll mean he lost the election by a wide margin, and I don't see that being likely.

Pennsylvania will be hard fought. Biden has natural strengths, being his birth state and cultural similarities to the state, but this state is also full of the "Obama-Trump" voters and many "Ancestrally Democratic" voters in the central part of the state which is "very Appalachia", arguably the most pro Trump tribe in the country. PA has all the markings of the metropolitan North East USA, Appalachia, and the Midwest in the greater Pittsburgh area. Still polls show Biden running consistently up and the Phili area he will run strong. Advantage Biden
Biden will regain working class support and continue to gain in the suburbs.

This election will confirm PA as a true swing state, something it masqueraded as for nearly three decades. The president needs PA to win and will pull out all the stops to make it happen. This will be one of the hardest fought states in the campaign. I thought about it for a while and though it is not out of the question to see a candidate not named Biden or Trump become one of the major party nominees, I cannot foresee a third party candidate winning the state. I gave it a sliver of probability just to show the chance is not zero.

Polls favor Biden, but, the polls favored Clinton throughout 2016... Biden has a better history here though.  Trump barely won here and this state has fewer paths to suppress voters than other states like Florida, Ohio and Wisconsin.  Biden should win PA by a touchdown this time.
Pennsylvania loves Trump (quietly) ... and too many people there actually know Joe Biden.
Swing voters in urban areas of state will move to the relatively stable democratic candidate.
270 to win shows it split even so that means Trump is going to win
The electoral map is going to be a sweep for Biden
Taking an average of my previous forecast, the new economist model, and the JHK model.

They are looking for financial hope, to have the ability to make it in America and not give their hard earned money to the government to be give always to healthy people, who chose not to contribute to society.
MId-term elections split the state. Latest polling has been dismal for Trump

Trump won PA by 44,000 votes in 2016. African-American turnout was lower for Clinton than for Obama.  Biden has more support among African Americans than Clinton so turnout might be higher this time around. Also if Biden picks an African-American VP candidate it would help. Also, Trump is polling lower among suburban voters compared to 2016.
Tide is turning against Trump - cant see it coming back

It was a very close win the last election for republican party. It will get corrected this year because the traditional industries (that republican candidates wanted to revive) have not made a return with a sustainable momentum.
pittsburgh and philly control the vote
Pennsylvania voters won’t make the same mistake as 2016 and will come out and vote.
Biden has Scranton roots and he is NOT for banning fracking.

The affluent suburbs of Philly and to a lesser extent Pittsburgh will tip the state, and won't be amenable to suppression or apathy as in 2016.  COVID is the only reason I'm assigning 25 percent possibility to the GOP initially.
Recent opinion polls.   Trump is struggling as President and Penn seems very winnable for Democrats.

PA is one of the main swing states that will decide the election. Given the decline of the economy, the coronavirus pandemic, and many other issues I think most of Trump's incumbency advantage is nullified. Obviously, a long way to go, but right now Biden appears to be slightly favored.

This will be one of the cliff hangers on election night.  Whoever can motivate voters the most can take the win.
All things being equal Biden will win but if we see a strong economy in the 3rd quarter or if we have elevated tensions with China/Iran/North Korea then the odds move to Trump.  Whoever wins will do so by a small margin.
Trump was the first Republican to win Pennsylvania since 1988, and he only won by less than 50k votes. Pennsylvania will swing back to its more traditional DNC support this election cycle.
Still too early... a VP like Harris would make Biden a shoo-in but Warren is too liberal for central PA.

Polls are mostly favoring Biden [1, 2], with only one poll on 538 (marked as "partisan") shows Trump with a lead. Biden's lead is in the single digits. There is no Senate race in PA this year (though senate is one each, R &D), and the incumbent reps are split down the middle (9 each R & D) [3]. 2016 pres results were based on 50k votes out of 6 million [4].  In a normal year, this would be a flip of the coin, but based on Biden's tight ties to the mid-Atlantic states, including being from PA [5], and working-class / union identification, that seems to give him a bit of a leg up, even against the standard incumbent advantage. Ending with a small advantage to Biden. [1] https://electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Pres/Graphs/pennsylvania.html
[2] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/pennsylvania/
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_congressional_delegations_from_Pennsylvania#Current_Representatives
[4] https://www.nytimes.com/elections/2016/results/pennsylvania
[5] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden

Not many polls, but looks like Biden has a single digit lead. https://projects.jhkforecasts.com/presidential-forecast/
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/pennsylvania/
